content: In this article, I will show my 3 favourite terminal with implementation of ZSH shell...
title: My Custom Linux Terminal

content: In this article, I will show my 3 favourite terminal with implementation of ZSH shell.
title: My Custom Linux Terminal

content: ZSH Shell ZSH is an amazing shell that just makes everything a bit easier from auto suggestions, autojump and completing tasks you do regularly considerably faster. Theme I’m using for ZSH is Powerlevel10k.
title: My Custom Linux Terminal

content: Terminal Kitty is very fast and configurable, uses threaded rendering for absolutely minimal latency and designed for power keyboard users. Main config file is kitty.conf Alacritty is a modern terminal emulator that comes with sensible defaults, but allows for extensive configuration and manages to provide a flexible set of features with high performance. Main config file is lacritty.toml Terminator has become The Robot Future of Terminals. Gnome based terminal, It has multi window support and great tiling function. Definitely one of the best to ssh into different remote machines. Main config file is terminator.conf
title: My Custom Linux Terminal

content: Requirements If you are Arch user you need to install AUR package manager git clone "https://aur.archlinux.org/yay.git" cd yay makepkg -si --noconfirm yay -Sy
title: My Custom Linux Terminal

content: How To Install I built a script to install and customize terminal. Script only support distributions based on Debian and Arch. Check the script here on my github. git clone git@github.com:vukilis/terminal_zsh_script.git cd terminal-zsh-script ./terminal-setup.sh
title: My Custom Linux Terminal

content: When I want to copy existing VMs to create a new project / VM, my new created VM have...
title: Changing UUID for VirtualBox VMs

content: The Problem When I want to copy existing VMs to create a new project / VM, my new created VM have the same UUID. So, if I try to open newly copied VM, error message apear where says that I can’t run VM because already existing one with same UUID.
title: Changing UUID for VirtualBox VMs

content: The Solution Open Terminal and navigate to folder where you have installed Oracle Virtual Box. Run next command twice to generate an UUID: $ VBoxManage internalcommands sethduuid "VDI/VMDK file location" Open the .vbox file in a text editor Replace the UUID found in Machine uuid="{…}" with first generated UUID replace the UUID found in HardDisk uuid="{…}" and in Image uuid="{}" (located at the end of the file) with second generated UUID
title: Changing UUID for VirtualBox VMs
